sp.l: O Priam, yield not to him!

sp.speaker: ANDROMACHE
sp.l: Do not, dear father.

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.l: Andromache, I am offended with you.
Upon the love you bear me, get you in.

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: This foolish, dreaming, superstitious girl
Makes all these bodements.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: O farewell, dear Hector.
Look how thou diest! Look how thy eye turns pale!
Look how thy wounds do bleed at many vents!
Hark, how Troy roars, how Hecuba cries out,
How poor Andromache shrills her dolor forth!
Behold, distraction, frenzy, and amazement,
Like witless antics, one another meet,
And all cry “ Hector! Hector’s dead! O, Hector!”

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: Away, away!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Farewell.— Yet soft! Hector, I take my leave.
Thou dost thyself and all our Troy deceive.

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.l: You are amazed, my liege, at her exclaim.
Go in and cheer the town. We’ll forth and fight,
Do deeds worth praise, and tell you them at night.

sp.speaker: PRIAM
sp.l: Farewell. The gods with safety stand about thee!

div.stage: Hector and Priam exit at separate doors.

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: They are at it, hark! Proud Diomed, believe,
I come to lose my arm or win my sleeve.

sp.speaker: PANDARUS
sp.p: Do you hear, my lord? Do you hear?

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: PANDARUS
sp.p: Here’s a letter come from yond poor girl.

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.p: Let me read.

sp.speaker: PANDARUS
sp.p:
A whoreson phthisic, a whoreson rascally
phthisic so troubles me, and the foolish fortune of
this girl, and what one thing, what another, that I
shall leave you one o’ these days. And I have a
rheum in mine eyes too, and such an ache in my
bones that, unless a man were cursed, I cannot tell
what to think on ’t.— What says she there?

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart.
Th’ effect doth operate another way.
Go, wind, to wind! There turn and change together.
sp.stage: He tears up the paper and throws the pieces in the air.
sp.l: My love with words and errors still she feeds,
But edifies another with her deeds.

sp.speaker: THERSITES
sp.p:
Now they are clapper-clawing one another.
I’ll go look on. That dissembling abominable varlet,
Diomed, has got that same scurvy doting foolish
young knave’s sleeve of Troy there in his helm.
I would fain see them meet, that that same young
Trojan ass that loves the whore there might send
that Greekish whoremasterly villain with the sleeve
back to the dissembling luxurious drab, of a sleeveless
errand. O’ th’ t’other side, the policy of those
crafty swearing rascals— that stale old mouse-eaten
dry cheese, Nestor, and that same dog-fox,
Ulysses— is proved not worth a blackberry. They
set me up, in policy, that mongrel cur, Ajax, against
that dog of as bad a kind, Achilles. And now is the
cur Ajax prouder than the cur Achilles, and will
not arm today, whereupon the Grecians begin to
proclaim barbarism, and policy grows into an ill
opinion.
sp.stage: Enter Diomedes, and Troilus pursuing him.
sp.p: Soft! Here comes sleeve and t’ other.

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: Fly not, for shouldst thou take the river Styx
I would swim after.

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Thou dost miscall retire.
I do not fly, but advantageous care
Withdrew me from the odds of multitude.
Have at thee!

sp.speaker: THERSITES
sp.p:
Hold thy whore, Grecian! Now for thy
whore, Trojan! Now the sleeve, now the sleeve!

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.l: What art thou, Greek? Art thou for Hector’s match?
Art thou of blood and honor?

sp.speaker: THERSITES
sp.p:
No, no, I am a rascal, a scurvy railing
knave, a very filthy rogue.

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: I do believe thee. Live.

sp.speaker: THERSITES
sp.p:
God-a-mercy, that thou wilt believe me!
But a plague break thy neck for frighting me!
What’s become of the wenching rogues? I think
they have swallowed one another. I would laugh at
that miracle— yet, in a sort, lechery eats itself. I’ll
seek them.

div.head: Scene 5

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Go, go, my servant, take thou Troilus’ horse;
Present the fair steed to my Lady Cressid.
Fellow, commend my service to her beauty.
Tell her I have chastised the amorous Trojan
And am her knight by proof.

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.l: I go, my lord.

sp.speaker: AGAMEMNON
sp.l: Renew, renew! The fierce Polydamas
Hath beat down Menon; bastard Margareton
Hath Doreus prisoner,
And stands colossus-wise, waving his beam
Upon the pashèd corses of the kings
Epistrophus and Cedius. Polyxenes is slain,
Amphimachus and Thoas deadly hurt,
Patroclus ta’en or slain, and Palamedes
Sore hurt and bruised. The dreadful Sagittary
Appals our numbers. Haste we, Diomed,
To reinforcement, or we perish all.

div.stage: Enter Nestor, with Soldiers bearing the body of Patroclus.

sp.speaker: NESTOR
sp.l: Go, bear Patroclus’ body to Achilles,
And bid the snail-paced Ajax arm for shame.
There is a thousand Hectors in the field.
Now here he fights on Galathe his horse,
And here lacks work; anon he’s there afoot
And there they fly or die, like scalèd schools
Before the belching whale; then is he yonder,
And there the strawy Greeks, ripe for his edge,
Fall down before him like a mower’s swath.
Here, there, and everywhere he leaves and takes,
Dexterity so obeying appetite
That what he will he does, and does so much
That proof is called impossibility.

sp.speaker: ULYSSES
sp.l: O, courage, courage, princes! Great Achilles
Is arming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengeance.
Patroclus’ wounds have roused his drowsy blood,
Together with his mangled Myrmidons,
That noseless, handless, hacked and chipped, come to him,
Crying on Hector. Ajax hath lost a friend
And foams at mouth, and he is armed and at it,
Roaring for Troilus, who hath done today
Mad and fantastic execution,
Engaging and redeeming of himself
With such a careless force and forceless care
As if that luck, in very spite of cunning,
Bade him win all.

sp.speaker: AJAX
sp.l: Troilus, thou coward Troilus!

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Ay, there, there!

sp.speaker: NESTOR
sp.l: So, so, we draw together.

sp.speaker: ACHILLES
sp.l: Where is this Hector?—
Come, come, thou boy-queller, show thy face!
Know what it is to meet Achilles angry.
Hector! Where’s Hector? I will none but Hector.

div.head: Scene 6

sp.speaker: AJAX
sp.l: Troilus, thou coward Troilus, show thy head!

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Troilus, I say! Where’s Troilus?

sp.speaker: AJAX
sp.l: What wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: I would correct him.

sp.speaker: AJAX
sp.l: Were I the General, thou shouldst have my office
Ere that correction.— Troilus, I say! What, Troilus!

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: O traitor Diomed! Turn thy false face, thou traitor,
And pay the life thou owest me for my horse!

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Ha! Art thou there?

sp.speaker: AJAX
sp.l: I’ll fight with him alone. Stand, Diomed.

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: He is my prize. I will not look upon.

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: Come, both you cogging Greeks. Have at you both!

div.stage: Troilus exits, fighting Diomedes and Ajax.

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.l: Yea, Troilus? O, well fought, my youngest brother!

sp.speaker: ACHILLES
sp.l: Now do I see thee. Ha! Have at thee, Hector!

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.l: Pause if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: ACHILLES
sp.l: I do disdain thy courtesy, proud Trojan.
Be happy that my arms are out of use.
My rest and negligence befriends thee now,
But thou anon shalt hear of me again;
Till when, go seek thy fortune.

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.l: Fare thee well.
I would have been much more a fresher man
Had I expected thee.
How now, my brother?

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: Ajax hath ta’en Aeneas. Shall it be?
No, by the flame of yonder glorious heaven,
He shall not carry him. I’ll be ta’en too
Or bring him off. Fate, hear me what I say!
I reck not though I end my life today.

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.l: Stand, stand, thou Greek! Thou art a goodly mark.
No? Wilt thou not? I like thy armor well.
I’ll frush it and unlock the rivets all,
But I’ll be master of it.
Wilt thou not, beast, abide?
Why then, fly on. I’ll hunt thee for thy hide.

sp.speaker: ACHILLES
sp.l: Come here about me, you my Myrmidons.
Mark what I say. Attend me where I wheel.
Strike not a stroke, but keep yourselves in breath,
And, when I have the bloody Hector found,
Empale him with your weapons round about.
In fellest manner execute your arms.
Follow me, sirs, and my proceedings eye.
It is decreed Hector the great must die.

div.head: Scene 8
div.stage: Enter Thersites; then Menelaus fighting Paris.

sp.speaker: THERSITES
sp.p:
The cuckold and the cuckold-maker are at
it. Now, bull! Now, dog! Loo, Paris, loo! Now, my
double-horned Spartan! Loo, Paris, loo! The bull
has the game. Ware horns, ho!

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.p: Turn, slave, and fight.

sp.speaker: THERSITES
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.p: A bastard son of Priam’s.

sp.speaker: THERSITES
sp.p:
I am a bastard too. I love bastards. I am
bastard begot, bastard instructed, bastard in mind,
bastard in valor, in everything illegitimate. One
bear will not bite another, and wherefore should
one bastard? Take heed: the quarrel’s most ominous
to us. If the son of a whore fight for a whore,
he tempts judgment. Farewell, bastard.

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.p: The devil take thee, coward!

div.head: Scene 9
div.stage: Enter Hector, with the body of the Greek in armor.

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.l: Most putrefied core, so fair without,
Thy goodly armor thus hath cost thy life.
Now is my day’s work done. I’ll take my breath.
Rest, sword; thou hast thy fill of blood and death.

sp.speaker: ACHILLES
sp.l: Look, Hector, how the sun begins to set,
How ugly night comes breathing at his heels.
Even with the vail and dark’ning of the sun
To close the day up, Hector’s life is done.

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.l: I am unarmed. Forgo this vantage, Greek.

sp.speaker: ACHILLES
sp.l: Strike, fellows, strike! This is the man I seek.
So, Ilium, fall thou next! Come, Troy, sink down!
Here lies thy heart, thy sinews, and thy bone.
On, Myrmidons, and cry you all amain
“ Achilles hath the mighty Hector slain.”
Hark! A retire upon our Grecian part.

sp.speaker: A MYRMIDON
sp.l: The Trojan trumpets sound the like, my lord.

sp.speaker: ACHILLES
sp.l: The dragon wing of night o’erspreads the Earth
And, stickler-like, the armies separates.
My half-supped sword, that frankly would have fed,
Pleased with this dainty bait, thus goes to bed.
Come, tie his body to my horse’s tail;
Along the field I will the Trojan trail.

stage.stage: Sound retreat. Enter Agamemnon, Ajax, Menelaus, Nestor, Diomedes, and the rest, marching to the beat of drums.

sp.speaker: AGAMEMNON
sp.l: Hark, hark, what shout is this?

sp.speaker: NESTOR
sp.l: Peace, drums!

sp.speaker: SOLDIERS
sp.l: Achilles! Achilles! Hector’s slain! Achilles!

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: The bruit is Hector’s slain, and by Achilles.

sp.speaker: AJAX
sp.l: If it be so, yet bragless let it be.
Great Hector was as good a man as he.

sp.speaker: AGAMEMNON
sp.l: March patiently along. Let one be sent
To pray Achilles see us at our tent.
If in his death the gods have us befriended,
Great Troy is ours, and our sharp wars are ended.

div.head: Scene 11
div.stage: Enter Aeneas, Paris, Antenor, Deiphobus, and Trojan soldiers.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Stand, ho! Yet are we masters of the field.
Never go home; here starve we out the night.

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: Hector is slain.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Hector! The gods forbid!

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: He’s dead, and at the murderer’s horse’s tail,
In beastly sort, dragged through the shameful field.
Frown on, you heavens; effect your rage with speed.
Sit, gods, upon your thrones, and smite at Troy!
I say at once: let your brief plagues be mercy,
And linger not our sure destructions on!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: My lord, you do discomfort all the host.

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: You understand me not that tell me so.
I do not speak of flight, of fear, of death,
But dare all imminence that gods and men
Address their dangers in. Hector is gone.
Who shall tell Priam so, or Hecuba?
Let him that will a screech-owl aye be called
Go into Troy and say their Hector’s dead.
There is a word will Priam turn to stone,
Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives,
Cold statues of the youth and, in a word,
Scare Troy out of itself. But march away.
Hector is dead. There is no more to say.
Stay yet. You vile abominable tents,
Thus proudly pitched upon our Phrygian plains,
Let Titan rise as early as he dare,
I’ll through and through you! And, thou great-sized coward,
No space of earth shall sunder our two hates.
I’ll haunt thee like a wicked conscience still,
That moldeth goblins swift as frenzy’s thoughts.
Strike a free march to Troy! With comfort go.
Hope of revenge shall hide our inward woe.

sp.speaker: PANDARUS
sp.p: But hear you, hear you!

sp.speaker: TROILUS
sp.l: Hence, broker, lackey! Ignomy and shame
Pursue thy life, and live aye with thy name!

sp.speaker: PANDARUS
sp.p:
A goodly medicine for my aching bones! O
world, world, world! Thus is the poor agent despised.
O traitors and bawds, how earnestly are
you set a-work, and how ill requited! Why should
our endeavor be so loved and the performance so
loathed? What verse for it? What instance for it?
Let me see:
sp.l: Full merrily the humble-bee doth sing,
Till he hath lost his honey and his sting;
And being once subdued in armèd tail,
Sweet honey and sweet notes together fail.
sp.p:
Good traders in the flesh, set this in your painted
cloths:
sp.l: As many as be here of panders’ hall,
Your eyes, half out, weep out at Pandar’s fall;
Or if you cannot weep, yet give some groans,
Though not for me, yet for your aching bones.
Brethren and sisters of the hold-door trade,
Some two months hence my will shall here be made.
It should be now, but that my fear is this:
Some gallèd goose of Winchester would hiss.
Till then I’ll sweat and seek about for eases,
And at that time bequeath you my diseases.
